dashboard.description:
# Virtualization - Operate Virtual desktops and applications publishing come with the promise to decrease hardware costs and improve operations; what used to take hours to deploy can be done in minutes. To ensure successful adoption of Virtualization, you must know if the experience of these users is on the level they require to be efficient in their daily business. The Virtualization - Operate module will help you ensure this and compare the experience of your VDI users to that of your physical device users.
# Overview Dashboard This dashboard gives an overview of your physical and virtual device landscape.
::: tip The **Average user interaction** indicates the average daily interaction of a user with their device. This value can help you understand the daily usage of physical and virtual devices. Note that if a user does not use their device on a particular day, the value for that particular day is not taken into account in the average. :::
::: configuration The category **hardware type** defines if your device is classified as physical or virtual. To change the default tagging rules, [edit the hardware type][1]. :::
[1]: nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Hardware%20type&Type=source
dashboard.name: Overview

titleConfig.title: Digital Experience Score and Sub Score Breakdown

dashboard.description:
# SBC Application experience
**Understand SBC Application Performance** * It is important to understand at an Application Level across the SBC Landscape, which Applications are responding well, which are using the most resource and where there this indicates action must be taken. If an application is using too much resource, it should be considered to be removed from the SBC setup, or the SBC Systems using it must be resized to be more powerful. If an application is taking too long to respond, then the network activity must be looked at.
**Understand SBC Application Availability** * If Applications are crashing or freezing across the SBC landscape, of if the amount of crashes or freezes increases, this must be understood by looking into those Applications.
::: configuration * By default all applications will be included in the dashboard. To limit the number of applications that are included, please populate the category 'VDI - Operate1 - Excluded Applications'. * The SBC Server systems should have been marked as such using the category 'VDI - Operate1 - SBC System'. * [Configuration guide](https://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/V6.24/LibraryPacksConfiguration/VirtualizationOperate) :::
dashboard.name: SBC Application Experience

dashboard.description:
# SBC Device experience
**Identify Overloaded SBC Systems** * Devices that are overworked may be impacting user Productivity. Use this dashboard to see both the number of SBC systems which are experiencing issues and also the top offenders listed so they can be directly addressed.
**Understand Network Issues on SBC Systems / Understand Traffic to Back End Systems** * Network issues for SBC systems may cause desktop freezing, glitching or straightforward application pausing and should be addressed. By combining this with a view on how much traffic is going to the back end systems the SBC systems infrastructure is talking to, may reveal unexpected traffic volumes which could be a contributing factor.
**Understanding SBC Availability** * Bluescreen crashes or Hard Resets are a clear indicator of unexpected behavior. If this figure shows signs of having any significant amount of devices, it should be looked into.
::: configuration * To visualize the traffic to Back End systems, the destinations for such systems must have been populated in the category 'VDI - Operate1 - Back End Systems' * [Configuration guide](https://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/V6.24/LibraryPacksConfiguration/VirtualizationOperate) :::
dashboard.name: SBC Device Experience

dashboard.description:
# Virtual device sizing
**Recommendations - Device Sizing** * If you are using an SBC Server then over-utilized or underutilized systems should be flagged as candidates to be removed or added to the landscape. This section reports on indicators of systems that are either over or under sized and should be addressed.
Use this dashboard to better balance the sizing of your virtual machines.
Devices that are **undersized** have reached the limits of their sizing, whereas **oversized** devices are using only a fraction of their potential. By better balancing the sizing depending on the actual device usage, you can improve the experience for your users with undersized devices whilst keeping the overall hardware resources under control.
**Least Used Applications** * Applications that are not being used do not provide benefit. This table lists the least used applications across your Virtual Infrastructure.
**Usage Intensity** * This table list for SBC environments how much overall resource your users are taking up. Candidates who have high or very high intensity should be examine, with a view to increasing the resources available to them or moving them back to a dedicated physical device.
**CPU sizing** Undersized: devices with more than 50% high CPU time. Oversized: devices with less than 1% high CPU time.
**RAM sizing** Undersized: devices with more than 50% high memory time. Oversized: devices with less than 1% high memory time.
**Hard drive sizing** Undersized: devices with more than 80% hard drive used. Oversized: devices with less than 30% hard drive used.
::: configuration * As these metrics are for SBC systems, the category 'VDI - Operate - SBC Server' must have been set on any SBC Systems. For Application usage, any applications which have been flagged with category "Virtualization - Operate - Excluded Applications" will be ignored. * [Configuration guide](https://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/V6.24/LibraryPacksConfiguration/VirtualizationOperate) :::
dashboard.name: SBC Sizing

dashboard.description:
# SBC Users experience
**Remediate SBC Users** * Users having a negative digital experience must be addressed. This view shows the resource utilization and network experience of users while they are using Virtual Sessions (SBC). As well as a status indicator for how many users are experiencing problems with a resource constraint, it also lists the top users by CPU, memory and network connectivity.
::: configuration * For SBC based metrics, the category ['Virtualization Operate - SBC Server'][1] must have been set on any SBC Systems. * [Configuration guide](https://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/V6.24/LibraryPacksConfiguration/VirtualizationOperate) :::
[1]: nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Virtualization%20-%20Back%20End%20Systems&Type=destination
dashboard.name: SBC Users Experience

dashboard.description:
# VDI Application Experience
This dashboard presents the experience of your users when using applications from their physical and virtual devices.
You can compare the application crash and freeze ratios and pinpoint the applications causing the most issues.
::: tip The **application crash ratio** and **application not responding event ratio** respectively indicate the number of application crashes and the number of application freezes per 100 executions. :::
dashboard.name: VDI Application Experience

dashboard.description:
# VDI Device Experience
Devices that are overworked may be impacting user Productivity. Use this dashboard to compare the end-user experience of your users using physical and virtual devices.
::: configuration * [Configuration guide](https://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/V6.24/LibraryPacksConfiguration/VirtualizationOperate) :::
dashboard.name: VDI Device Experience

dashboard.description:
# VDI Network Experience Compare your network quality concerning physical and virtual devices.
::: configuration * The **network response time** measures the average TCP connection establishment time of all underlying connections.
You can adapt these metrics to measure your most important response time; for instance, the response time when connecting to a critical service in your company. Click on the following links to [edit the response time for physical devices][1] and [edit the response time for virtual devices][2].
* To visualize the traffic to Back End systems, the destinations for such systems must have been populated in the category 'Virtualization Operate - Back End Systems'
[Configuration guide](https://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/V6.24/LibraryPacksConfiguration/VirtualizationOperate) :::
[1]: nxt://Edit-NxMetric?Encoding=Url&Name=Virtualization%20-%20Operate%20-%20Average%20network%20response%20time%20on%20physical%20devices [2]: nxt://Edit-NxMetric?Encoding=Url&Name=Virtualization%20-%20Operate%20-%20Average%20network%20response%20time%20on%20virtual%20devices
dashboard.name: VDI Network Experience

dashboard.description:
# VDI Sizing
**Recommendations - Device Sizing** * If you are using VDI Desktops then over-utilized or underutilized systems should be flagged as candidates to be removed or added to the landscape. This section reports on indicators of systems that are either over or under sized and should be addressed.
Use this dashboard to better balance the sizing of your virtual machines.
Devices that are **undersized** have reached the limits of their sizing, whereas **oversized** devices are using only a fraction of their potential. By better balancing the sizing depending on the actual device usage, you can improve the experience for your users with undersized devices whilst keeping the overall hardware resources under control.
**Least Used Applications** * Applications that are not being used do not provide benefit. This table lists the least used applications across your Virtual Infrastructure.
**Usage Intensity** * This table list for VDI how much overall resource your users are taking up. Candidates who have high or very high intensity should be examine, with a view to increasing the resources available to them or moving them back to a dedicated physical device.
**CPU sizing** Undersized: devices with more than 50% high CPU time. Oversized: devices with less than 1% high CPU time.
**RAM sizing** Undersized: devices with more than 50% high memory time. Oversized: devices with less than 1% high memory time.
**Hard drive sizing** Undersized: devices with more than 80% hard drive used. Oversized: devices with less than 30% hard drive used.
::: configuration * As these metrics are for VDI. For Application usage, any applications which have been flagged with category "Virtualization - Operate - Excluded Applications" will be ignored. * [Configuration guide](https://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/V6.24/LibraryPacksConfiguration/VirtualizationOperate) :::
dashboard.name: VDI Sizing

dashboard.description:
# VDI Users experience
**Remediate VDI Users** * Users having a negative digital experience must be addressed. This view shows the resource utilization and network experience of users while they are using Virtual Sessions (VDI). As well as a status indicator for how many users are experiencing problems with a resource constraint, it also lists the top users by CPU, memory and network connectivity.
**Overall Logon Speed Summary** * Nexthink measures and scores logon speed into a scoring system of normal and slow. Any users experiencing a slow logon should be investigated. The slowest logon users are displayed to assist in getting started.
::: configuration * [Configuration guide](https://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/V6.24/LibraryPacksConfiguration/VirtualizationOperate) :::
dashboard.name: VDI Users Experience

dashboard.description:
# Virtualization Compliance
This view allows you to ensure that the virtual agents are in good working order. if these are not in good working order, this can cause connection problems to users and an inability to manage agents through virtual infrastructure.
::: configuration The metric used for this dashboard use the **Virtualization - Operate - Virtual Agent** category.
:::
dashboard.name: Virtualization Compliance
